result.markdown:
---
title: "Statistical Concepts"
---


# Assignmnet


::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_da5e3a58faa0d537a15828b25c1eef70'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Load the file
random_vars <- readRDS("Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
str(random_vars)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> Classes 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame':	1000 obs. of  2 variables:
#>  $ age   : num  21 34 10 68 15 50 32 14 17 26 ...
#>  $ income: num  940 6678 22 2392 74 ...
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Create a Data Frame
df1=data.frame(random_vars)
# 1.Find the values of mean, variance and standard deviation
```
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_2b72136d64830c0a7947701053a474ef'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 1.Mean 
mean(df1$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 33.471
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
mean(df1$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 3510.731
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_b73ae7833dbb93732f67732c1c52db62'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 2. Variance
var(df1$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 340.6078
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
var(df1$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 8625646
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_2d090a798f02c38175885fd0954eb6ae'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 3. Standard deviation
sd(df1$age)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 18.45556
```
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sd(df1$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 2936.945
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_ed6d7ddd8abb47bf2cc1f1e21dbd92f7'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 2. The calculated Standard deviations are on vastly different scales. In this case, the large difference in values suggests that the Data Sets corresponding to these standard deviations have very different degrees of variability. Due to this reason it does not make sense to compare them.
```
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-6_d460525b91ae243fbfa5bdace1162584'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 3 Calculate Covariance and Correlation
cov(df1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#>               age     income
#> age      340.6078   29700.15
#> income 29700.1468 8625645.84
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-7_38a6d74366df6785e8cff231afc5248d'}

```{.r .cell-code}
cor(df1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#>              age    income
#> age    1.0000000 0.5479432
#> income 0.5479432 1.0000000
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-8_5cd1022f952d72a7fd476074156afc81'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 4. Correlation is generally easier to interpret and compare than covariance especially when dealing with variables on different scales.It provides a standardized measure of the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.
```
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-9_74fd0180e9f0f731d1dcecede29e1683'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# 5. Conditional Expected value
age_18 <- subset(df1, age<=18, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 389.6074
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-10_b7a483a00fe078859a07f11f664c7b71'}

```{.r .cell-code}
age_65 <- subset(df1, age>=65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_65$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 1777.237
```
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-11_296006ab5b9bdc1a5c365af2d3e75e15'}

```{.r .cell-code}
age_18_65 <- subset(df1, age>=18 & age<65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18_65$income)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
#> [1] 4685.734
```
:::
:::
